properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is occurring over some areas near Lake Huron. Dense areas of fog have developed near Lake Huron and are expected to persist into the overnight hours. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in areas prone to frost Thursday night. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea water levels are expected, possibly exceeding high astronomical tide. Wave heights: generally 6 to 8 metres with higher waves possible, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: Burin and Connaigre Peninsulas. Time span: continuing this evening. Remarks: Long-period swells and very large waves are expected to continue along the south coast as Post-Tropical Storm Teddy tracks towards the island. These waves may coincide with high tide to produce elevated water levels, with potential for local flooding and coastal erosion, especially along south-facing shorelines. Damage to coastal infrastructure may occur. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-09-24T04:59:58-00:00

Area: Burin Peninsula, Connaigre
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A series of vigorous frontal systems will move across the south coast of BC today through Saturday. They will bring periods of heavy rain and strong winds in the first active storm cycle of the the fall season. The first system will spread rain to Vancouver Island and the mainland today and Thursday. Rainfall intensity will vary through the day and across regions. Over Vancouver Island, total rainfall amounts over the two day period will generally range from 15 to 40 mm, with amounts in excess of 100 mm over West Vancouver Island. For the mainland coast, total rainfall amounts will range from 30 mm to over 50 mm for the two day period. The heaviest rainfall amounts are currently expected near the mountains. This system will also bring strong southeast winds to the west coast of Vancouver Island early this morning. Strong winds over the Strait of Georgia and surrounding regions will peak early this morning. Winds will diminish later today, but gusty conditions will continue. Tonight and Thursday, unsettled conditions will bring a risk of thunderstorms across the region as well. The combination of heavy rain with leaves on the ground may lead to localized flooding. Strong winds may also lead to power outages. The wet pattern will continue with more rain expected Friday and Saturday. Rainfall and wind warnings are now in effect for some regions, and will be updated as needed. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-24T08:40:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T16:41:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2297195534.2020
Area: East Vancouver Island - Duncan to Nanaimo, East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay, East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River, West Vancouver Island, Greater Victoria, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley, Metro Vancouver - southwest including Richmond and Delta, Fraser Valley - west including Abbotsford, Fraser Valley - central including Chilliwack, Fraser Valley - east including Hope, Southern Gulf Islands
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Today's heavy rainfall is the first storm in a week-long series that brings a major pattern change to the province of BC, in particular the south coast. Periods of rain, heavy at times, will continue through Saturday. Embedded thunderstorms and gusty winds are possible. This sudden change to a prolonged wet pattern combined with local gusty winds and trees shedding their leaves may lead to localized flooding. Strong winds may also lead to power outages. Late this week the pattern is intensified once again by a strong low pressure system crossing Vancouver Island Thursday night or Friday. Strong winds, and where they materialize, will depend on the exact storm track. Stay tuned to your local forecast throughout the week as we follow the evolution of this feature. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-24T11:09:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T19:10:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1895770033.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system approaching Baffin Island will bring gusty easterly winds to the Pangnirtung region tonight and Thursday. Winds will gradually increase this evening gusting to near 80 km/h overnight. In the vicinity of the higher terrain surrounding the community, wind gusts may possibly exceed 100 km/h. Strong winds will persist into Thursday morning but gradually moderate in the afternoon before diminishing further Thursday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, will continue today over the Lower North Shore and the eastern part of Anticosti Island as Post-Tropical Storm Teddy crosses the Gulf of St Lawrence. A total of 50 to 70 millimetres is expected before the rain ends this evening or overnight tonight. For more information on this system's development, please refer to Environment and Climate Change Canada's tropical cyclone information statement: https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/hurricane-forecasts-facts/products.html. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Periods of heavy rainfall will continue over Howe Sound, Metro Vancouver and the Fraser Valley late this afternoon and tonight. This moisture-laden system will deliver 40-70 mm of rain by Thursday morning. Embedded thunderstorms will bring additional localized amounts and rainfall rates of up to 20-30 mm/hr tonight. Rainfall rates will lessen on Thursday but persistent moist, onshore flow will cause showers, heavy at times, to continue Thursday. The heaviest rain amounts are expected near the mountains and eastern sections of the Fraser Valley. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels with large waves are expected near the coast. Locations: south facing shorelines from Port aux Basques to Burgeo-Ramea. Maximum wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Time span: continuing this evening, with the most severe conditions expected early this evening. Next high tide: 4 P.M. to 6 P.M. today. Remarks: Large waves and pounding surf will produce higher than normal water levels along the coast, especially near high tide. These large waves can cause damage to coastal infrastructure, especially at locations that have been prone to impacts during similar events in the past. ### Coastal flooding is possible along the shoreline. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Teddy. The next full statement will be issued by 3:00 P.M. ADT. Post-tropical storm Teddy made landfall in eastern Nova Scotia this morning and will continue to move northeastward as it weakens. 1. Summary of basic information at 12:00 P.M. ADT. Location: 46.3 north 61.6 west. About 15 kilometers northwest of Port Hood. Maximum sustained winds: 100 kilometers per hour. Present movement: northeast at 35 kilometers per hour. Minimum estimated central pressure: 970 millibars. 2. Summary of latest information. Based on satellite presentation, radar and recent observations along coastal Nova Scotia, post-tropical storm Teddy made landfall close to 10 AM this morning near or just east of Sheet Harbour. Confirmation from a private weather station and one of our own suggests Teddy's pressure was around 965 mb. The pressure will continue to rise in the coming hours. Very strong south to southeasterlies have been observed just to the east of the center. Hart Island reported a peak wind of 108 km/h and a gust to 104 km/h in Eskasoni, on Cape Breton Island. Forecaster(s): Mercer/March ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-09-24T04:59:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T14:25:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2456150579.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 3:59 p.m. PDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing strong wind gusts, pea to dime size hail and heavy rain. A line of severe thunderstorms over Tofino will continue moving southeastward this evening at 20 km/h, impacting communities along west coast Vancouver Island. Rainfall rates of 20-30 mm/hr are possible. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. A line of thunderstorms has produced rainfall rates of 20-30 mm/hr over northwestern Vancouver Island this afternoon. Heavy downpours associated with this line may move over communities located in the Inland Vancouver Island region, including Gold River and Port Alberni late this afternoon. Communities across East Vancouver Island from Campbell River to Cowichan could also be affected by heavy downpours from late this afternoon to early this evening. ### Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Teddy. This will be the last full information statement issued for Post-Tropical Storm Teddy. A final intermediate statement will be issued by 12:30 A.M. NDT. Post-Tropical Storm Teddy continues to track towards northern Newfoundland and out into the Labrador Sea on Thursday. 1. Summary of basic information at 9:30 P.M. NDT. Location: near 49.7 North 58.2 West. About 130 kilometres north of Stephenville. Maximum sustained winds: 85 kilometres per hour. Present movement: northeast at 50 kilometres per hour. Minimum estimated central pressure: 978 millibars. Teddy continues to move northeastward off the west coast of Newfoundland. It's likely to maintain its intensity before reaching the Labrador Sea on Thursday. 2. Public impacts and warnings summary: a. Wind. Wind and Tropical Storm warnings have now ended for Channel-Port-aux-Basques and vicinity and Burgeo - Ramea however wind gusts of 70 to 80 km/h are still expected this evening. b. Rainfall. Some residual moisture from post-tropical Teddy may give some locally heavy rain across portions of southeastern Labrador tonight. c. Surge/Waves. Large waves and high water levels will subside this evening over southwestern Newfoundland. 3. Marine impacts and warning summary: Post-Tropical Storm Teddy will continue to produce waves of 7 to 9 metres east of the storms track into the southwest coast of Newfoundland this evening, but will begin to subside overnight. Forecaster(s): March/Mercer/McArthur ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-09-24T16:59:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T23:48:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2642598025.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada
